title: portugal among 12 destinations international travel green list
story: Portugal is the only major holiday destination to make the “green” list for quarantine-free travel with many of the other 11 countries still banning tourists or with tough restrictions.The move foreshadows a surge in bookings for holidays to Portugal, which has already seen flights double in price in anticipation of its inclusion on the green list.The limited list also provoked an angry reaction from the travel industry who demanded the Government indicate which countries could be included in the future reviews of the list, due every three weeks.The only other potential mainstream “holiday” destinations that made the “green” list are Iceland, Gibraltar and Israel, which have either limited capacity for tourists or place tough conditions for visitors.Grant Shapps, the Transport Secretary, admitted the list - including Australia, New Zealand and Singapore which remain closed to foreign visitors - represented a “necessarily cautious” and “tentative” resumption of international travel from May 17.Other popular European destinations including Greece, France, Spain and Italy are on an amber list which requires any holidaymakers to quarantine for ten days on their return and take two PCR tests.Malta, the holiday island which had been expected to be on the green list, also only made amber but could turn green when the list is reviewed three weeks after the May 17 re-start of foreign travel.The only other countries or territories on the green list are Brunei, Faroe Islands, Falkland Islands, South Georgia, South Sandwich Islands, St Helena, Ascension Island and Tristan de Cunha.Tourists are not permitted to visit Brunei or the Falkland Islands, while any visitors to the Faroe Islands are required to have a “special worthy purpose” for their trip.St Helena, Ascension Island and Tristan de Cunha have a mandatory 14-day quarantine period. Travellers arriving in South Georgia and the South Sandwich Islands who are not fully vaccinated must self-isolate for seven days on arrival.Three countries - Turkey, the Males and Nepal - are added to the red list - which requires any Britons returning to the UK to quarantine for 10 days in Government approved hotels at a cost of £1,750 per person.At a Downing Street press conference, Mr Shapps defended the cautious approach: We in this country have managed to construct a fortress against Covid. But the disease is still prevalent in other parts of the world, most notably at the moment in India.In fact, more new cases of Covid have been diagnosed around the world in the last seven days than at any time since the pandemic began.That's why today's announcement, removing the stay in the UK restrictions from May 17, is necessarily cautious. We must make absolutely sure that the countries we reconnect with are safe, that their infection rates are low and their vaccination rates are high.It means making sure we are not incubating the most dangerous variants that they're not and that they have safe and secure surveillance in place.Mr Shapps indicated that there would be more countries added to the “green” list throughout the summer. It will be reviewed every three weeks from May 13, although Government sources are still being cautious about whether popular destinations such as France, Italy, Greece and Spain would be added by the end of June.In the meantime, Mr Shapps urged Britons to avoid travel to “amber” list countries as he warned that the extra border checks which all holidaymakers face on their return would mean longer queues at airports. “You should not be travelling to these places right now,” he said.By contrast, Portugal is gearing up for a major reopening of travel after May 17 when it will only require Britons to show proof of vaccination or a negative Covid test result.There was already a spike in prices this week for flights to Portugal after the Foreign Office ditched its advice against non-essential travel to the country.British Airways was on Thursday night charging £530 for a flight from Heathrow to the Algarve on May 17, compared with £234 for the same route two days earlier.A Ryanair flight from Stansted to Portugal's capital Lisbon on May 17 was £152, compared with £15 on May 16. And EasyJet was charging £234 for a flight from Luton to the Algarve on May 17, but just £73 the following day.Two of the other green list “holiday” destinations still have restrictions. Israel will only accept vaccinated holidaymakers and requires a test for biological proof of it. Travel to Israel is expected to be limited to select group tours from May 23 and only open to independent tourists from July.Iceland requires even vaccinated travellers to quarantine until they have taken a PCR test to prove they are negative for Covid. Other visitors are required to take a test on arrival and quarantine until a second negative test result on day five or six.Gibraltar will allow in Britons without a PCR test, but has limited capacity for any surge in tourists.The list provoked strong criticism from the aviation and travel industry after a year in which foreign travel has been largely at a standstill.Karen Dee, chief executive of the Airport Operators Association, said: “It is disappointing that so few countries are on the green list. This is not yet the meaningful, four-nation restart UK airports and the economy need.”Tim Alderslade, chief executive of Airlines UK, said: “This is a missed opportunity and with so few countries making it onto the green list represents a reopening of air travel in name only.“By contrast the EU has said vaccinated people will be able to travel without restrictions which leaves the UK at risk of falling behind and not opening up international travel to key markets across Europe as well as the United States.”EasyJet boss Johan Lundgren called on the Government to provide clarity about which countries could be added to its green travel list.Gloria Guevera, head of the World Travel &amp Tourism Council said: “After suffering the biggest fall in contribution towards GDP from travel and tourism of the 10 most important global markets - by a staggering 62.5 per cent - the UK can ill-afford to be this cautious.”What are the entry rules for green and amber destinations? Travellers should check requirements on the Foreign Office travel advice gov.uk website. Much of Europe will require a negative PCR test result for entry andor proof of vaccination or immunity through having had the virus. Some green list countries such as Australia and New Zealand are closed to most arrivals.Where do I get a test for my holiday, and when should I book?There are two options: ordering a home test kit or booking an appointment at a clinic or drive-through test centre. Test providers are expecting a surge in customers when travel opens up, so if you need a test for your destination, book as soon as possible.Where can I get a return test, and when should I book it?Holidaymakers returning from “green list” destinations will be required to take a test within 72 hours before they arrive back in the UK. This can be a lateral flow test. These are free to order through gov.uk.You will then need to take a PCR test on or before the second day of your return. These should be booked as soon as possible once you have reserved your holiday. Costs are coming down to £60 per test, with TUI offering it for £20 to green list destinations.Which countries will be in demand and will prices increase?Portugal is the only main popular European holiday destination on the quarantine free green list, as Spain, France, Italy and Greece have been categorised as “amber” under the traffic light system.There may be interest in amber list countries for those prepared to quarantine and in Gibraltar, Israel and Iceland. However, it is searches for “Portugal holidays” that have already increased 110 per cent over the past seven days.Airlines operate systems where prices rise in line with demand. However, tour operators may be less likely to increase their costs.Emma Coulthurst from TravelSupermarket said: “There weren’t price hikes for package holidays last summer and package holiday providers need to sell holidays. It is in the industry’s interest to get people away. TUI, for example, has said this morning... that its packages are in line with last year’s prices and that it won’t be looking to put up prices.”More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: scientists want people keep working home indefinitely
story: Government scientists want people to work from home indefinitely, even though the latest data suggests the roadmap out of Covid lockdown is on track.The latest figures show infection levels are now the lowest they have been for eight months, with just one in 1,180 people in England having Covid.Next week, the  Scientific Advisory Group for Emergencies (Sage) is expected to publish more data showing the impact of Britain's vaccine programme, with cases dropping despite the reopening of outdoor hospitality and non-essential shops and the return of schools.The projections will also examine the impact of the next steps, with sources suggesting any increase in cases is not expected to be on the scale of previous virus waves.After the roadmap was published, related modelling suggested a full release of restrictions in June could trigger a new wave of hospitalisations as bad as the January peak.The latest modelling – taking in a slew of data including research showing that one vaccine dose can cut virus transmission by half – is expected to paint a far more positive picture. But Government scientists are understood to be concerned that progress could be undermined if people return to work in significant numbers, increasing social contact. They are calling for those who can work from home to continue doing so, saying employers should plan so that staff can stay at home or spend limited time in the office until the threat of the global pandemic recedes. One source said there was no reason to return to an office full-time after June 21 if work could be carried out at home. Boris Johnson is expected to set out the next stages in the exit from lockdown next week, with people allowed to mix indoors in groups of up to six or two households, and pubs and restaurants allowed to serve indoors from May 17.Under the current timetable, limits on social distancing will be lifted on June 21, but the Government has yet to set out policies about the return of workers to the office. A decision on whether face masks will be required on public transport has also yet to be taken. Modelling produced for the Government suggests people will not go back to pre-pandemic levels of contact with others as restrictions lift. Papers released by Sage on Friday show that last August, people were still only at about 50 percent of their pre-pandemic contact levels with other people.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: telegraph weekly news quiz social media platform has upheld
story: In the week that a row over post-Brexit fishing rights between the UK and France escalated, the 's weekly news quiz is here to find out how closely you have been paying attention to this week's headlines.A G7 meeting took place in London this week, but the foreign minister of which country was forced to pull out of attending the meeting in person after two Covid-19 cases were detected in the nation's travelling delegation?In America, the oversight board of which social media giant has upheld a ban on former US president Donald Trump from using the platform?If you've been reading this week's  Front Page newsletters you will have come across all of the answers to the quiz. If you haven't, you can sign up for the newsletter from the 's Danny Boyle and Chris Price to revise ahead of next week's quiz. If you're looking for last week's quiz, you can find that here. Right, good luck and no cheating. 1010: Quite remarkable. You're in the upper echelon of expert  quizzers.7-910: A solid score but we'll see you back here next week for full marks. 4-610: Nothing to see here. Let's pretend that this week's performance didn't happen.0-310: Pathetic. Don't give up on the day job. For more ways you can have your say and get involved, visit the  Community HubSign up for the 's Front Page newsletter to find all of the answers to next week's quiz. ​More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: time boris decide wants achieve
story: As an inflatable Boris Johnson bounced around outside the count in Hartlepool, where was Keir Starmer? Back in London, which arguably tells you everything you need to know about his continued failure to reconnect with a Red Wall that is now bluer than an episode of The Smurfs.After a year of reminding everyone he is not Jeremy Corbyn, SurrKeir was hoping for cut-through but instead he appeared to be largely cut dead up North. Working-class voters clearly don’t take kindly to seeing an overly Brylcreemed politician poncing about in John Lewis when the pubs remain closed for indoor pints. Starmer appeared so ridiculous eyeing up that gold wallpaper precisely because he is the ultimate “magnolia” politician who stands for everything and nothing.While Labour childishly drones on about all that is wrong with the world, without seemingly doing a jot about it, the Tories have managed to vaccinate more than half the adult population. These things do not go unnoticed by the electorate, which is probably why no one could be bothered to make a Starmer blimp.But as he once again basks in post-election glory, the Prime Minister must seize the moment to move his premiership into its next, and most important, phase.We have sat through the lively and upbeat first movement of the Boris opera, the “campaign” piece, featuring players such as Australian political strategist Lynton Crosby and Dominic Cummings (until he came over all Norma Desmond in Sunset Boulevard). Johnson hit all the right notes as he persuaded the British public that he would “get Brexit done” and eviscerate “that crazed Communist”.Then came a pandemic-sized interval, when the leading man was stretchered off stage, leaving the rest of the cast lost for words in his absence. Amid scenes of chaos and confusion, the middle “managerial” movement finally swept in with a new team of productive staff taking centre stage. Whitehall’s “safest pair of hands” Simon Case was appointed Cabinet Secretary while former Merrill Lynch banker Dan Rosenfield replaced Lord “Steady Eddie” Udny-Lister as Johnson’s chief of staff. With a cameo from Kate Bingham, who led the Government’s vaccine task force, the Boris Show was back on track – and following Thursday’s local election results, it is now being asked to perform an encore.Yet as any discerning opera fan knows, it is this next movement that really matters.For ultimately, Johnson is not going to be judged on all that has gone before – but on what happens in the final act of his administration as it enters the post-Covid era and attention switches to him winning a second term in office.If the Tories are going to make their advances in places like Hartlepool stick then there is only so long the Prime Minister can continue to belt out slogans about “levelling up” and “building back better” without providing the rest of the script.Having put their trust in the Tories, many for the first time, voters in the Midlands and the North will want to see some improvement in their lives and local areas by the time the next general election rolls around. However, it is not clear that anybody in No 10 has any idea how Johnson’s soundbites will translate into action. And if appointing Harborough MP-turned-lockdown-zealot Neil O’Brien to do some of the thinking is the answer, then it is time to look again at their cast list.As with any performance, the chances of a standing ovation depend on the star soloist – but also those in support in the wings. If Johnson is going to be remembered like his hero Churchill, then those accompanying him not only have to read his mood music but also play all the right notes.Currently, there is no Lennon to his McCartney, which remains an ongoing problem inside No 10. It is frankly staggering that the Prime Minister ended up as a lone voice in Downing Street on lockdown, so frustrated by the lack of support that he was allegedly left to vent in his office about rather seeing “bodies piled high in their thousands” than shutting down the economy again last October.Although Tories will hardly be surprised at the lack of loyalty from the likes of Michael Gove, who stabbed his former Vote Leave running mate in the front during the 2016 leadership race, it seems a sorry state of affairs that there is no Osborne to Johnson’s Cameron no Campbell to Johnson’s Blair.Being anything but beige (unlike his Opposition rival), the Prime Minister has always been rather difficult to manage. Leadership is a lonely place as it is, but throughout his time behind the black door, Johnson appears to have been surrounded by very few people who seem to understand him. It is partly his own fault, since at times he appears more inscrutable than the Queen playing poker in Ray-Bans. His penchant for quietly contemplating the options before him without seemingly giving a firm indication of his preference was once described by a Cabinet minister as a form of “Japanese silence”.Yet when he was at City Hall, there were experienced and influential people like Sir Lynton, the late great, Simon Milton, and the spin doctor Will Walden who knew how to read him. His ex-wife Marina Wheeler also knew what made him tick – but the power base in Downing Street has shifted to allies of his fiancée Carrie Symonds, like Henry Newman and Meg Powell-Chandler who, while they may be competent advisers, could hardly be described as Boris whispherers. This must change if the PM is to achieve his dream of a legacy of longevity.I understand No 10 has already been subtly casting the net for long standing allies to return to the fold in a bid to decode and implement Johnson’s political ideology. The recruitment of HM’s highly regarded former private secretary Lord Geidt is certainly a step in the right direction. Having spent a decade reading the monarch’s mind and dealing with squabbles between the Prince of Wales and the Duke of York, he should find Downing Street a doddle. The former intelligence officer has just been taken on as the independent adviser on ministers’ interests – but he may well be minded to put the Prime Minister’s interests at the top of his in-tray.More from NewsMore from The Back to topSyndication and CommissioningTerms and ConditionsWe urge you to turn off your ad blocker for The  website so that you can continue to access our quality content in the future.Visit our adblocking instructions

title: elections 2021 uks future hangs
story: NewsElections : UKs future hangs in balance as SNP majority too close to callNicola Sturgeon is battling for an outright majority at the Holyrood elections to secure another independence referendummirrorShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political EditorLizzy BuchanPolitical Correspondent:,  MAY NewsNicola Sturgeon is gunning for an outright majority in the Holyrood elections " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeThe future of the United Kingdom is hanging in the balance as the SNPaposs hopes of securing a majority for independence were too close to call. First Minister Nicola Sturgeon is bidding for an outright majority to boost her claim for another independence referendum.But she played played down the likelihood of an overall SNP majority at Holyrood earlier in the day, saying it has always been a very, very long shot.The final result is expected on Saturday, with the SNP claiming the bulk of the declared seats on Friday night. Some  seats are needed to secure a clear majority. See the latest results below By pm, the party had won  out of  declared seats for the -seat Scottish Parliament. The SNP picked up seats in East Lothian and Ayr as well as scooping former Scottish Tory leader Ruth Davidsonaposs Edinburgh Central seat. But Labouraposs Jackie Baillie held on to her Dumbarton constituency - the most marginal seat in Scotland - and a top target for the SNP. Ms Baillie had a majority of just  from the  Holyrood election, but she increased that to , on Friday. Labour also held Edinburgh Southern, while the Lib Dems retain four seats, including Orkney Islands, Shetland Islands, North East Fe and Edinburgh Western.The Tories have kept three seats - Eastwood, Dumfriesshire, and Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire. Speaking at her count in Glasgow, Ms Sturgeon signalled her plan to press ahead with demanding another independence vote. She said: “At this stage I am extremely happy that the SNP appears to be on course for a fourth consecutive election victory, and to be on course to have the privilege of forming a government again. “If that is indeed the outcome of this election, I pledge today to get back to work immediately, to continue to steer this country through the crisis of Covid, to lead this country into recovery from Covid – and then, when the time is right, to offer this country the choice of a better future.”

Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeJust four countries on the governmentaposs newly-unveiled aposgreenapos travel list will allow Brits to holiday without quarantining.This evening it was announced that  countries and territories have made the list, including Portugal, Israel, Gibraltar, Australia and New Zealand.Also included were Singapore, Brunei, Iceland, the Faroe Islands and the Falkland Islands, alongside the Azores and Madeira territories in Portugal. But before excited tourists packing their bags and book a flight, itaposs important to note that heading to some of these destinations will mean they must spend the first few days of their trip isolating - and some will not let them in at all. Only Portugal, including the Azores and Madeira, and Gibraltar are open to Brits without quarantining - with Iceland and Israel also not enforcing isolation but requiring holidaymakers to be vaccinated. Despite being on the green list, people will not be able to go on holiday to Australia, New Zealand or Singapore, as they are closed to UK tourists. People arriving in the Faroe Islands are required to take a test on arrival and self-isolate for  days, although there is an option to release after four days with a PCR test. Foreigners touching down in Brunei will have to pay £ for a Covid test, and can be made to quarantine for up to two weeks, according to latest travel advice. Andyouaposre heading to the Falkland Islands, itaposs best to book a long break as visitors are expected to self-isolate for a period of  days after arrival. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. The countries were selected because of low Covid infection rates, good progress with vaccinations and the absence of known mutant strains. However the government has advised holidaymakers to be cautious as regulations could changethe situation in any of the countries worsens. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said the removal of international travel restrictions was necessarily cautious and that the Government must make absolutely sure the countries the UK reconnects with are safe. He said: We in this country have managed to construct a fortress against Covid. But the disease is still prevalent in other parts of the world, most notably at the moment in India.  In fact, more new cases of Covid have been diagnosed around the world in the last seven days than at any time since the pandemic began. He added: Thataposs why todayaposs announcement, removing the stay in the UK restrictions from May , is necessarily cautious. We must make absolutely sure that the countries we reconnect with are safe, that their infection rates are low and their vaccination rates are high. It means making sure we are not incubating the most dangerous iants that theyaposre not and that they have safe and secure surveillance in place.

title: kevin maguire 8 ideas labour
story: NewsopinionMy  ideas Labour can use to climb the queasily high election mountainAfter a torrid night at the polls for Labour, the Mirrors Kevin Maguire gets going with some ideas the party could use to fight its way back to powermirrorShareCommentsByKevin MaguireAssociate editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY Newsopinion" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeDialling , booking a one-way ticket to Dignitas or buying a Lottery ticket and hoping arenapost realistic options so Keir Starmer and Labour face some hard thinking. Crushing defeat in Hartlepool, lost council seats and failing to take back mayoral posts from Boris Johnsonaposs Conservatives leaves Labour still tumbling down an already queasily high electoral mountain. What Labour must do to win again isnapost easy but to start a national conversation here are eight ideas to get the talking started: . What is Labour for  Fundamental yet too many voters donapost know and when they do, donapost like it. Starmer must paint in vivid colours the fairer, stronger, better, more prosperous country heaposd build. The NHS is Labouraposs greatest, most enduring gt to the nation but it needs to offer more than championing a single public service. . Good Policies The perception Labour lacks policies is the ugly twin of too many voters ignorant of what it stands for. Practical, attractive plans and ideas to improve lives that can be shouted from roof tops would fill gaps. . Be Relevant Here the party has to appeal to people in jobs as well as the jobless, self-employed and employed, middle earners and low waged, private and not just public sector workers plus the old alongside the young. One Labour MP complained too many of his constituents thought it represented only benefit claimants and migrants. Thataposs a bigoted caricature and both groups deserve representation anyway but it must appeal to self-interest as much as altruism.  . Optimism Beats Pessimism Be upbeat about the potential of people and Britain and what could be achieved. The triumphant can-do spirit is infectious. The historic mindset of the Left is failures, sell-outs and betrayals. When the countryaposs riddled with injustices and inequalities, families and communities held back, this isnapost a moment for champagne but Labour optimism for change would go a long way. . Culture Matters Locally and nationally, many take pride in their area and the nation. Criticism of Starmer for appearing on TV with union flags is ludicrous. Tories focus on statues to ert people. Brexit serves a similar role. Redefine patriotism as championing British values of fairness and decency - and stop the Tories hijacking flags.

title: labour admit london mayor race
story: NewsLabour think London mayor election is close as Tory Shaun Bailey even eyes possible upsetThe prospect of a Shaun Bailey shock victory is still looking very faint - but Labour sources are saying the race is closer than most people thought it would bemirrorShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsTory mayoral candidate Shaun Bailey is claimed by The Times to believe he can win " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeLabour sources are saying the London mayoral election is closer than people thought - as Tories even appear to start eyeing a possible upset.Labouraposs Sadiq Khan was widely expected to romp home to a second term by a wide margin when final results come on Saturday night, after polls put him way ahead of Tory Shaun Bailey. But a Labour source today told the Mirror the London race was definitely closer than people were thinking.The source insisted that, despite polls putting Mr Khan comfortably ahead, we always said it would be a close election. Under Londonaposs election rules, the top two candidates in the first round will then go through to a second round, and pick up any second-preference votes from people who voted for smaller parties. Mr Khanaposs team still appeared to believe heaposs likely to triumph on second preferences, however.  The source said: There is no question we are seeing signicant impact from turnout and voters believing they could put a smaller party first preference without influencing the election result. There are still half of London boroughs to count and it’s too early to say anything with any certainty at this stage. And Pollster Chris Curtis, of Opinium, tweeted on Friday night: If Shaun Bailey gets elected Mayor of London I will run around City Hall naked. A YouGov poll this week had tipped Mr Khan to win % in the first round and Mr Bailey % - narrowing the gap between the pair by five points. However, YouGov had said an upset looked unlikely as in the second round, Mr Khan would triumph with % compared to Mr Baileyaposs %. As of .pm on Friday, Mr Khan had around % of the first-round votes counted compared to Mr Baileyaposs % - although that included earlier-declaring, Tory-voting outer boroughs in the capital so is not a reliable tally. The Times reported tonight that Mr Baileyaposs campaign believed he could actually win the London mayoralty. Another source close to the Tory appeared less optimistic, though, telling the Guido Fawkes blog: It’s closer than everyone thinks. Still a long way to go though, but Shaun will have beaten the polls by a fair whack. The speculation comes despite a string of gaffes by Mr Bailey, including claiming people would spend a Universal Basic Income on lots of drugs.  It comes after Keir Starmer said he would do whatever it takes to rebuild after a bitterly disappointing defeat in the Hartlepool by-election. Tory Jill Mortimer snatched the seat from Labour with a majority of nearly , votes in a stunning victory for Boris Johnson.And there was further misery for the party in the local elections as Labour lost control of Harlow, Rossendale and Sheffield councils - and failed to make any major gains as the first results came in. The result sparked immediate recriminations, with Labouraposs left wing piling in to criticise Mr Starmeraposs leadership. In a terse statement, he said: Iaposm bitterly disappointed in the result and I take full responsibility for the results - and I will take full responsibility for fixing this. We have changed as a party but we havenapost set out a strong enough case to the country.

title: lets call red bridge not
story: NewsopinionLets call it a Red Bridge not a Red Wall - Labour needs to find common groundLabour needs to stop listening to people in silos, and pitting dferent groups interests against each othermirrorShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  MAY NewsopinionLabour leader Sir Keir Starmer is facing a backlash after the party was trounced in the Hartlepool by-election " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeSometime in , after covering the ‘Troubles’ in Northern Ireland as a series of running battles at Drumcree and on the streets of Belfast, I went to the first meeting of the Northern Ireland Women’s Coalition. I was surprised to find around  women from both sides of the sectarian ide talking about the things they had in common. The decent education no one’s child was getting, the state of the local health service. The fact their kids were growing up surrounded by violence. Instead of focusing on the issues that ided them, these women were working together to get things done in the common good. As Hartlepool joins the long list of towns land-sliding away from Labour, another brick in a red wall fallen into a Tory sea, Labour needs to start a similar process. The Left’s civil war may only appear to be political, but every day out of power is costing lives, livelihoods and futures just the same. The answer to losing Hartlepool is neither to expel Momentum or get the first bus back to Corbynism. It is to ask young politan voters to sit with older town-based voters and thrash out a party and policies they could both agree on. Three blindingly obvious examples spring to mind. A Green jobs revolution in Labour’s former industrial heartlands that would combine the younger part of the movement’s desire for huge environmental change and bring jobs to held back and long neglected areas. Post-pandemic is the perfect time to rip up the rule book on public spending to challenge the climate emergency. And at their heart, towns just really want to flourish again, after years of decline. Secondly, an all-out attack on the gig economy. This should be at the absolute heart of Labour’s policies as gig corporates roll back the clock on labour rights and reforms to pre-Victorian times. Gig jobs are ruining the lives of care-workers in Hartlepool just the same as Deliveroo riders in Bristol. A shared agenda for change could immediately alter people’s lives meaningfully for the better. Thirdly, the rebuilding of a health and social care service fit for the roaring s and beyond, and that meets the challenges of an ageing population with dignity for both carers and the cared for. To achieve this, Labour needs to be once again a party of all the talents, dominated neither by one faction or another. Witness Joe Biden’s confident leadership, that has brought in people from across the Democratic spectrum. Witness also his economic radicalism. Just as Trump’s radicalism has ripped open politics in the US, the radicalism of Brexit has done the same in the UK, paving the way for new ideas. It’s not good enough for Labour to keep saying it is listening. The party needs to engage in active listening. It’s not good enough to sit in a pub with people and then just take back the things you already knew. This week I spoke to a man in Cumbria for our Britain Talks project who said he was now backing coal tobecause he’d given up hope of ever getting green jobs to his dying town.

title: local election results 2021 live
story: :root Local election results in full: Summary of all polls in England, Scotland and Wales so farThe results are coming in after a brutal night for Labour and Keir Starmer. This article will continue being updated with all the results as they come in between now and SundayLocal election results in full: Summary of all polls in England, Scotland and Wales so farThe results are coming in after a brutal night for Labour and Keir Starmer. This article will continue being updated with all the results as they come in between now and SundayVotes are being counted across Great Britain - this piece is bringing you all the results from all the pollsByDan BloomOnline Political EditorLizzy BuchanPolitical Correspondent:,  May Updated:,  May Labour is mired in another weekend of election misery after the Tories demolished a Red Wall brick to claim a stunning victory in the Hartlepool by-election. Keir Starmeraposs party suffered losses in a swathe of English council seats as voters shrugged off Tory sleaze revelations to back Boris Johnson. And in the Tees Valley mayoral contest, Conservative incumbent Ben Houchen trounced his Labour rival by a landslide, with % of votes to %. The West Midlands mayoral result, due on Saturday, could pile on the agony for Labour as Tory strategists are confident of victory for reigning mayor Andy Street. Even London’s mayor race, where Sadiq Khan had been set to romp home by a wide margin, is “definitely closer” than people thought, sources admit.   A fresh ballot box meltdown across England saw electors switch to the Conservatives following  years of Tory rule from Westminster – prompting another round of Labour soul-searching and tough questions for Mr Starmeraposs -month premiership. But the results are not all rosy for the Tories - whose vote share in Scotland was actually down in early counting. With the SNP gaining three Holyrood seats in early results, Nicola Sturgeon appeared to be inching close to a majority in the Scottish Parliament. That would allow her to launch a fresh and brutal push for independence - which could split the UK apart within just a few years. Results were also mixed for Labour, who appeared to be doing better in the Welsh Parliament election than they were in England. Labour held key Tory target seat Wrexham with a slightly increased vote share, while the party raised its vote share in Gower by % compared to the Tories’ %.  With  out of  Welsh Parliament seats declared Labour had upped its vote share by .% - though the Tories’ was also up by .%. That suggests Labour may still have to seek a coalition or other arrangement with smaller parties to govern in Wales. Results will continue to pour in until Sunday including for the Welsh and Scottish Parliaments, which are only starting to count this morning. But so you can keep track, weaposre publishing all the results so far on this article which you canto and refresh to see whataposs what. Please note that while our interactive tools should show full detailed results, our text service only includes highlights or seats changing hands in order to make this article easier to navigate. Text last updated pm Friday. Graphics update automatically. Big elections  at-a-glance HARTLEPOOL BY-ELECTION: The blockbuster Westminster ballot. The Tories wiped out Labour ’s , majority in the Brexit-backing northern seat - which has been red since its creation in . The Tory majority is now almost double what Labouraposs was before in a historic upset. Result now declared.  ENGLISH COUNCILS: More than , seats were up for grabs on  county,  unitary,  metropolitan and  district councils in England. Results across the country showed the Tories doing very well at Labouraposs expense - despite many of the seats that were up for election being lost by Labour last time. Labour lost a whopping  seats in traditional bellwether Nuneaton and Bedworth. The Tories snatched Harlow in Essex from Labour after seven seats changed hands and took Northumberland from no overall control. Dudley - where Labour and the Tories were practically neck and neck before - went to the Tories with a massive cull of red seats. Conservatives now have  seats, almost double Labouraposs . Labour was stripped of control in Sheffield as the council leader lost his seat and the Conservatives won their first on the authority for  years. Labour also lost nine councillors in Sunderland. Results Friday, Saturday and Sunday. SCOTTISH PARLIAMENT: All  seats are being chosen and Nicola Sturgeon was hoping to win an overall majority to push for independence - which she was just short of before. Early results showed SNP gains in key seats including Ayr, East Lothian and Edinburgh Central and a vote share up by .%. Itaposs not a landslide and was still too close to call on Friday nightthere would be an SNP majority. Nicola Sturgeon won in her seat but on a slightly reduced vote share, as Labour leader Anas Sarwar notched up more than , votes standing against her. Results Friday afternoon through to Saturday night. WELSH PARLIAMENT: All  seats were up for grabs and polls suggested Labour - while the biggest party - had an uphill struggle to win an overall majority. But the party was not suffering the collapse many feared, or that was seen in England. Only one of Walesapos so-called red wall seats, the Vale of Clwyd, fell to the Welsh Conservatives in early counting while Labour held Wrexham. Labour sources were also confident of unseating the former Plaid Cymru leader Leanne Wood in Rhondda. Results Friday afternoon and evening.  ENGLISH MAYORS: The biggest battles were over Tory-held West Midlands, Tees Valley and West of England, but Labouraposs hopes of making in-roads were fading fast. Tory Ben Houchen scored a massive victory in Tees Valley while Tory sources were confident of taking West Midlands. Even in London, where Sadiq Khan had been expected to easily romp home, Labour sources said the margin was closer than most people thought.West Midlands, West of England and London declare Saturday. LONDON ASSEMBLY: All  seats were up for election and Labour was straining for an overall majority. Results Friday and Saturday.  POLICE COMMISSIONERS: The oft-forgotten jobs in England and Wales were up for election for the third time since they were created in . Results through to Monday.  RESULTS IN DETAIL HARTLEPOOL BY-ELECTION Tory Jill Mortimer thrashed Labouraposs Paul Williams with , votes to his ,, declaring: The people have spoken and they’ve made clear it’s time for change. news politics local-elections--four-labour-"" %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeKeir Starmer is facing a major crisis after Labour shed a string of seats across England in the  elections. He has vowed to go further and faster in breaking from the Corbyn project - saying Labour has lost the trust of working people in places like Hartlepool. But that promise has angered the Labour left, who say Labour must now set out what it stands for and unveil policies that inspire the electorate. Sir Keir is expected to reshuffle his Shadow Cabinet and said today: Iaposm bitterly disappointed in the result and I take full responsibility for the results - and I will take full responsibility for fixing this. We have changed as a party but we havenapost set out a strong enough case to the country.  Very often we have been talking to ourselves instead of to the country and we have lost the trust of working people, particularly in places like Hartlepool. I intend to do whatever is necessary to fix that. Yet pressed repeatedly by journalists, Sir Keir failed to set out what actual policies he will use to inspire voters. Here, four MPs from radically dferent wings of the party give their view to the Mirror on what he should do next. John McDonnell: aposBlaming Corbyn wonapost washapos  When a political party loses an election like Hartlepool, it needs to have a deep and honest look at itself.Still trying to blame Jeremy Corbyn just won’t wash. First, he won Hartlepool in both the  and  elections and, second, he hasn’t been leader of the Labour Party for over a year. The reality is that with % of the people of Hartlepool voting for Brexit in , this issue still hung over the byelection.Plus, in a time of national crisis like the pandemic people do naturally rally round the government.Of course, Boris Johnson has also exploited the wonderful dedication and hard work of NHS workers in rolling out the vaccination programme to boost his own position. The fact that these NHS workers are the very people who are being insulted by him with a % pay offer is a disgrace.Apart from these special factors, the main problem for Labour in these elections was that people simply did not know what Labour stood for. Where Labour had strong mayoral candidates standing on strong local manestos, they secured a decent vote. Elsewhere the lack of any national party policy programme that explained Labour’s aims and ambitions meant people had no motivation or incentive to vote Labour. For a year the central message from Labour was nothing more than that it was under new leadership.  To win future elections any leadership must inspire voters by the vision of the society they want to create and the policies that will achieve it. Labour now needs to start that work urgently. That means Labour as a party rooted in our local communities, with a policy programme to tackle the bread and butter issues our people face and armed with a vision of the fairer, heathier, and greener Britain we aim Io create Wes Streeting: aposWeaposve taken too many voters for grantedapos  When you’ve slogged your guts out knocking on doors during an election campaign, there’s nothing more comforting than a nice warm bath. The Labour Party’s problem is that every time we lose elections, we always reach for the nice warm bath of reassuring excuses, instead of the cold shower of recognising why we lost and taking the action needed to win again. There’s a lot of focus on Hartlepool. But we took a beating in other areas of England, too. Keir Starmer ’s response to those results shows that he’s got the message. He understands the scale of Labour’s challenge and is up to meeting it.The question is, will Labour finally listen, learn and change  This is the first time in years that I’ve knocked on doors and the Leader of the Labour Party has been such a positive with voters. But as we’ve seen in England and Scotland, a change of leader isn’t enough. We have to prove that the Labour Party itself has changed. What do our defeats, under very dferent leaders, have in common  The voters think our priorities are not their priorities. They suspect our heart’s in the right place, but they’re not convinced our head is in the right place, too. It needs saying: Labour has taken too many voters for granted. Under successive leaders. Because we haven’t put voters’ concerns ahead of our own Party’s concerns. But we can, and must, turn that around. First, we must own up to this and admit our mistakes. Next, with Keir’s leadership, we put it right. That is the only way we move forward to winning ways. The only route back to Government for Labour. No more navel gazing. Time for action. Lloyd Russell-Moyle: aposWe need to become a left coalitionapos  Geographies donapost vote, people do. When we say traditional Labour heartland what we mean is traditional Labour people. On a night where Labour failed to regain areas we lost in  and didn’t break through in some of the southern and shire seats we needed traditional Labour people and new Labour people alike were cold on the current Labour brand. This is not unique to Labour, we see across western democracies Social Democrat parties which once relied on the coalition of blue collar workers and metropolitan liberals has fallen apart. How has this happened  Those of us on the left often say Labouraposs policies are very popular on economic, health, education issues Labour is much closer to the people than the Conservatives. After  years of austerity, however, there is a limit to how much local councils can blame Westminster for failing services and the voters buying the central government bogy man argument. That should mean in Conservative shires we are pushing at an open door full of potholes and closed libraries but in industrial and urban centres where Labour has traditionally ruled it was always going to be an uphill struggle. Social issues are proving dficult for Labour too. The Greens have managed to start to hit that sweet spot, their vote has rocketed and here in East Sussex they are taking seats.Only Joe Biden in the USA has managed to get the coalition back together. The USA’s “Uncle Joe” is able to be right-on social issues like Trans Rights without being woke, put forward relatively radical economic policies such as a  h federal minimum wage or a national broadband network and change the conversation around Trade Unions and industrial rebirth capturing forgotten and left behind communities.If Keir and Labour wants success, we need to revaluate how we build that coalition, doubling down on “new leadership” or flag waiving without the actual values of progressive patriotism will ring hollow and the voters have seen it. If Labour is also to survive we need to start to consider ourself not the Labour Party but the Labour Parties, geographically independent London, Scotland, Welsh, Cornish or Yorkshire parties but also an honest coalition of many outlooks: Greens, Momentum, Progress, Cooperative Party standing candidates under the Labour brand. Neil Coyle: aposPolicing, safety and job security must come firstapos

title: people hartlepool say keir starmer
story: NewsPeople of Hartlepool say Keir Starmer neglected working class voter in stark messageEXCLUSIVE: The Mirror did a tour of Hartlepool after Labour lost the by-election in yet another Tory demolition job, and heard from people who say they are not interested in wallpaper - and dont want a Remainer MPmirrorShareCommentsByJeremy Armstrong:,  MAY NewsNeighbours Peter Cook and William Crask spoke to the Mirror " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy notice The people of Hartlepool had a stark message for Labour leader Keir Starmer on Friday: You have forgotten your heartland - and neglected the traditional aposworking classapos voter.The Mirror did a tour of the town and its historic headland, where the statue of our very own Andy Capp stands proudly swathed in a rainbow scarf with a message of thanks to NHS staff for their work during the pandemic.Traditional Labour voters in the seat which the party had held since its creation in  admitted Andyaposs creator Reg Smythe, a Mirror legend and one of the townaposs most famous sons, would be aposturning in his graveapos as Boris Johnson celebrated victory.Conservative Jill Mortimer won the by-election with more than half of the votes cast, a swing from Labour of almost  percent. She took , votes, a majority of , over Labouraposs Dr Paul Williams. What is your view  Have your say in the comment section The heavens opened shortly after Johnson embarked on his victory tour here, doing a photo call with farmeraposs daughter Jill on the marina. Before today, the very words aposConservative MP for Hartlepoolapos would have seemed impossible. It does not rain but it pours for Labour as the Prime Minister rejoiced in yet another demolition job on the former aposRed Wallapos of Labour-held constituencies.Peter Cook, , a lelong Labour voter before the  General election, a trade unionist and former shop steward, said: The biggest mistake Labour made here was when they brought in a rejected former MP from Stockton who had supported Remain and attacked people who wanted to come out of Europe. I was disgusted, Brexit was the big issue for me - the vast majority of the town rejected staying in Europe.Pardon my French, I think Boris Johnson has made a right b**** of it especially for the fishing industry in this country. I had previously voted Labour, but I donapost knowI will vote for them again in my letime. And he warned Keir Starmer that he needed to get out of the Westminster bubble - and fast. I am not interested in Borisapos wallpaper, he said. We need to look at where things are going wrong.  There was a time when two steelworks here, we had engineering, we used to make things. Not any more. We canapost let China produce everything. We want aposcan doapos politicians who get things done -Labour had good ideas, people would vote for them. His next door neighbour on the historic town wall, William Crask, , a dad-of-two and production operator, had the same message. From coronavirus to Brexit, our daily politics newsletter is there to guide you these turbulent times. The newsletter is sent out twice daily with the latest UK  world politics news, along with leading opinion and analysis.You can sign up here.  Labour has lost its way, he said. I am a working man, and the fact is that they donapost represent me anymore. They are for public servants, the middle class, people on benefits. Butyou are a working class person, in a normal job, they just donapost seem to care. I did not vote Labour last time when I had before, because I was for Brexit.  But it is not just about that, they donapost talk about investment, they donapost seem to have any policies, they donapost have a vision. Boris makes mistakes but he is just himself, and people donapost seem too worried about his faults.I voted for Tony Blair Labour went wrong with Ed instead of David Miliband.It was all downhill from there. The Labour party is trying to please everybody, and pleasing nobody.  Brexit is done, gone, and we need to move on from that. We need jobs, investment, not just all mouth and no action. Actions speak louder than words. In her victory speech, Jill Mortimer warned Labour had taken local people for granted for too longapos. Many agreed with that view, and spoke of the work of Tees mayor Ben Houchen in bringing investment to the area. Elizabeth Maughan, , a mum-of-three who works in a local newsagent, did not vote for Labour this time because she was so aposdisillusionedapos.  We have so much anti-social behaviour where we live, people smashing windows, and I am working and paying full council tax, she said. I have always voted Labour - my mother would be turning in her grave - but they have not done anything for Hartlepool. I could not vote Tory mind. Outside the Pot House pub, a popular spot with beautul views out over the town harbour, there were many who had turned Tory, however. Frank Boagey, , a retired steel erector who paid his union dues during a -year career, turned his back on Labour for the first time in  after lelong support.  All my family were fishermen, there was no way I was going to vote against Brexit, he said. This is not a dictatorship. The people of Hartlepool voted to leave the EU and Labour would not go with the majority view, which is what you do in a democracy. Mandelson was an embarrassment for me and so were the last two Labour MPs. If you had given Peter Mandelson a pin, he could not have found Hartlepool on the map before he came here and now he is Lord Mandelson of Hartlepool, it really is a joke. They kept on dropping people in here who know nothing about the place, taking the voters for granted.  I was a trade unionist for  years and voted Labour for  years and suddenly thought aposwhat have they done for me apos Retired local Government officer Edith Ward, , a great grandmother, was one of the few dissenting voices. But she was not surprised that Labour lost, and urged the party to do more to win back the traditional working class voters. I think people have forgotten all the huge mistakes made at the start of the pandemic, the thousands of lives lost as a result of those mistakes, she said. I voted against Boris. But Labour have got to try harder to win this back, and prove they are better than people think right now.  They do need to make a change. Her friend Ann Murray, , a retired office clerk, great grandmother and former Labour voter, went for a local candidate as she felt more needed to be done aposfor the North eastapos. Independent Sam Lee took her vote and , others, with . percent overall, as Tories took huge gains from the , who voted Brexit last time. Hartlepool-born Christine Appleyard, , on a visit to see her school friend Julie Sladen, , described the result as a aposbloody tragedyapos.

title: who won local elections live
story: NewsWho won local elections where I live  Search the results in your areaResults are pouring in across England, Scotland and Wales between now and the end of Sunday. Search for the results where you live using our interactive postcode toolmirrorShareByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsThe Tories overturned a majority of around , in the Westminster seat of Hartlepool " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get US and UK politics insight with our free daily email briefing straight to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.When you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Your information will be used in accordance with ourPrivacy Notice.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeLabour have had a grim night in the  elections after losing the Hartlepool by-election and a string of English council seats.The Tories overturned a majority of around , in the Westminster seat - Labour for  years - and doubled it in the other direction.The newly elected MP described it as a momentous day and claimed Labour had taken people in the area for granted for too long.But the elections are about far more than one Westminster by-election, however wounding for Keir Starmer.The vast majority of English councils are counting on Friday and Saturday, along with the Scottish Parliament. The Welsh Parliament is aiming to do all its counting later today. Key English mayoral battles will also be announced later on Friday and over the weekend.For a full rundown of results timings click here and for and for the full schedule of results so far click here.Butyou want to see the results so far through your postcode, you can enter it in the interactive tool below: It came as Steve Reed, shadow secretary for communities and local government, said the defeat in Hartlepool was absolutely shattering. Speaking on BBC Breakfast, he said: I congratulate Jill Mortimer on her victory, but it was for me, as a Labour Party member, absolutely shattering to see a Conservative MP elected in a place like Hartlepool after nearly  years.I think what this shows is that, although we have started to change since the cataclysm of the last general election, that change has clearly not gone far enough in order to win back the trust of the voters, and weaposve just seen that in spades in Hartlepool.Labour MP Diane Abbott, who was shadow home secretary during Jeremy Corbynaposs leadership, branded it a crushing defeat for Labour and urged Sir Keir to rethink his strategy. She tweeted: Not possible to blame Jeremy Corbyn for this result. Labour won the seat twice under his leadership. Keir Starmer must think again about his strategy.Both the Prime Minister and Sir Keir visited the Hartlepool constituency three times during the campaign.
