But for socio-linguists, like Rob Drummond of Manchester politan University, it was ldquofascinating.ldquoGeorge Galloway is embodying some well-worn stereotypes regarding the relationship between accent, identity, social class, and even character, the academic said. ldquoItrsquos an unusual stance to take during elections, as surely it simply serves to alienate signicant sections of the population.ldquoHe is explicitly putting some accents on a higher-status-level than others, and seems to be accusing BBC Scotland of knowingly using this hierarchy to undermine the perception of Scotland from outside. He clearly sees one accent as representing the underclass, and another accent as representing the elite.Politicians may not often punch down. But they sometimes, Mr Drummond says, punch up, referring to ldquoposh" Etonians. ldquoThis is, of course, still an example of accent prejudice, but arguably it is happening in the direction where the imbalance of power makes it less recognisable as such, he says.He and his colleagues have been cataloguing examples of accentism, as the BBC and other TV and radio channels widen the range of speech they broadcast.They have good news. ldquoThere is still a long way to go, but there are perhaps signs that things are changing, Mr Drummond explains. ldquoThere are suggestions that younger people do not hold the same stereotypes and attitudes towards particular accents as older people. And there is clearly a lot more ersity within broadcasting as a whole than there was  or  years ago. Also, there is simply so much more voice media around than there was [more TV, podcasts, social media, youtube etc]. Hopefully, all this exposure will have an effect.This was a TikTok election, a campaign when soundbites were not just for the evening TV news, and when everybody could have their say ndash out loud, recorded for posterity.There are still those who struggle with linguistic ersity, who think more iety makes less sense, who yearn for the certainty of a prestige dialect or accent, whether it is RP or standard Scottish English . But standardisation means less understanding, not more. It loses us so much nuance, so much identity so much poetry of place. Only speaking SSE or RP is like only painting in monochrome. Itrsquos dull.Later today we will find out who voters in Dumbarton have chosen as their voice, Mr Giugliano or Ms Baillie. Either way it will be somebody whose speech tells a story. We should respect that,  times over, for every seat in Holyrood.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: letters-bring-back-university-graduations-summer-let-families-bring-boost-local-economy
story: Rules surrounding restricted activities have been changing month by month and it should not be beyond the wit of experienced academics to restructure graduations to fit. Scotland will be out of lockdown by the summer months and the university has "oven-ready" annual graduation plans that could easily adapt. Students and their families would certainly race to mody plans to attend.Students have paid the university dearly for their courses over several years and arguably deserve a little pageantry and photo opportunities to celebrate their success now that rules and restrictions are being relaxed. The late Prince Philip, as we all know, fully understood and championed the uplting effects of a little pageantry. In addition, many students have felt aggrieved at having to pay for unnecessary student accommodation over the past year. Moreover, since March  students have been forced to accept online lectures, an experience far short of perfect, with many laboratories and other elements of their courses cancelled. A graduation ceremony would go a long way to lessening the effect of feeling short-changed over the past year of their course.Might you challenge Glasgow Universityto adapt and act swtly to put some form of graduation in place for the summer  Families supporting graduations would bring a welcome and measurable boost to the hotel and restaurant trade across the city.Ruth Walden, Cambridgeshire.PUTTING FOOD WASTE TO GOOD USEIAIN Gulland, CEO of Zero Waste Scotland is quite correct to highlight the scandal of food waste in Scotland . Most local authorities provide a bin for residents to put their food and garden waste in, for weekly or fortnightly collection and recycling, many miles from the point of collection. However, for anyone with a garden or allotment there is a much simpler, easier, and cheaper solution Using pallets or other waste wood, why not construct a home-composting system  Nearly all food waste, with the possible exception of meat and fish, can be put in your bin add grass cuttings, cardboard , shredded paper, annual weeds, some seaweed, and horse or cow manure. When full, turn into an empty bin and start filling the first one again. By the end of a summer you will have a large bin full of nourishment for your garden for next year. Simply spread on the soil and the worms will do the rest.Rose Harvie, Dumbarton.CREDIT TO THE MEMORY BANKTODAYS pre-breakfast reading of your first batch of letterswas a depressing experience of claim and counter-claim, lessened by Celia Judges amusing lampooning of party leaders.Casting an eye to the second page of letters, I noticed another contribution by Thelma Edwards. My cornflakes tasted better than usual as I read another from Mrs Edwards seemingly inexhaustible supply of reminiscences.I look forward to many more.David Miller, Milngavie.ROYAL ETIQUETTE ON A KNIFE-EDGEJANICE GRANTnotes that her late mother used to say you could tell good breeding by the way someone held their kne. Attending a smart luncheon, I was amongst guests from mixed backgrounds, including HM The Queen. The chairman took it upon himself to advise us on the correct way to hold our cutlery.I was amused to note that the Queen failed to get the memo. Or did she William Douglas, Balfron.BRIEFS ENCOUNTERDOUG Marrrsquos dismay at the dullness of the run-up to Mayrsquos elections , brought back memories of robust political debates held in Glasgow University Union in the s.In particular, one featuring on stage the long-time medical student, Labour luminary J Dickson Mabon , President of GU Union -, the Scottish Union of Students -, later long-serving and respected politician, and an opposing feisty young lady lawyer, which drew the comment from the floor: ldquoWersquove had Dick Mabon, can we now have the ladyrsquos briefs R Russell Smith, Largs.OOH, I SAY...I WOULD suggest the actual comment made vis a vis Mike Winters Glasgow Empire entrywas somewhat more scathing and irreverent than reported. The phrase quoted, "Oh no, theres two of them", does not have the true ring of a Glasgow Empire audience pathos.Allan C Steele, Gfnock.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: Driving Ms DougieDOUGLAS Ross may have had yet another mediocre outing in Tuesdayrsquos BBC debate, but at least he had a first class ride home. Fellow politicos were stunned to see a chauffeur, in full unorm and cap, standing to attention and holding his car door open afterwards. Not even the First Minister had such luxury. Despite forever distancing himself from Boris Johnson, it seems Mr Ross nevertheless shares his love of the good le. Althoughhe keeps unimpressing the voters, we suspect it might soon become ldquoTaxi for Ross!Volga languageMOST party leaders shied away from press conferences this week in case they stuck their foot in it. But Alex Salmond gave it a go. As is traditional, the Alba party leader was asked about his work for a ruble-splashing TV channel. His programme, he insisted, was more balanced than some on BBC Scotland. ldquoWe are extremely biased, he flapped. A Freudian slip, or just letting Vladimir know alls well Defective defectorsWE also hear Alba has been desperate to find some big name SNP defectors this week, but the turncoat hunt has not turned out well. Recent endorsements have therefore been rather underwhelming - Les Huckfield, last a Labour minister in, er,  Alasdair Stephen, who, um, came third for the SNP in Skye in the  general election and, sigh, Inverclyde councillor Jim McEleny, who dramatically declared he was voting Alba to elect the top candidate on the West Scotland list, one Chris McEleny. Chris just happens to be his son. Tough call, pops!Family businessTALKING of families, when hes not leading Scottish Labour, Anas Sarwar is an obsessive video game player, as his kids will attest. "I like to pretend to them that Im doing some really, really important work on my phone, and instead Im probably playing Football Manager," he confessed to hacks this week. Mr Sarwar ended his campaign with a plea to tackle child poverty. He should ask his mum. According to his MSP register of interests, she was the biggest donor to his recent leadership fight, giving a handy pound,. Thatrsquos one way to tackle it. Cannily, this was half the pocketmoney she gave him in , when he lost to duffer Richard Leonard. Citizen SmithFINALLY, irony bypass of the week came from SNP MP Alyn Smith. Appearing on a Radio  discussion, he was scathing about the first-past-the-post system used at Westminster.ldquoA dreadful system of electing people, it really is, he fumed. As the SNP may be about to win a majority at Holyrood solely on the back of FPTP MSPs, he may want to rethink that. Unspun also raised its eyebrows at Alynrsquos remark to Tory MP Lee Rowley on the show. ldquoLee makes the point that independence is isive. Well, I would dispute that...

title: nicola-sturgeon-confronted-right-wing-candidate-jayda-fransen-glasgow
story: The First Minister blasted Ms Fransen as a "fascist and a racist", and predicted the -year-old would be rejected by voters on the the Southside of Glasgow, where she is standing as an independent candidate in Ms Sturgeons constituency.Ms Fransen, a convicted racist, was deputy leader of the alt-right Britain First organisation, and later formed the British Freedom Party.She was was found guilty of religiously shyaggravated harassment and ordered to pay a fine of pound after she targeted a Muslim mother of four who was wearing a hijab in Luton in November .Ms Fransen was also convicted of a other religiously aggravatedharassment in , which saw her sentenced to  weeks in prison:Former leader of Britain First to stand in Scottish elections against Nicola SturgeonIn a video posted on social media, the alt-right activist is seen approaching Ms Sturgeon in the street before asking her to apologise for "mass immigration and Marxism".She tells Ms Sturgeon: ldquoWhat are you sorry for  Mass immigration, Marxism ldquoIrsquom not a fascist. Irsquove been on the ground speaking to locals who say you are an absolute disgrace hellipHer supporter - a man with a Glasgow accent, who is filming - then begins to shout slurs at the First Minister."Youre a fascist and a racist." ###Massive kudos to @NicolaSturgeon for facing down these far right thugs.pic PkrtgaJbkResponding, Ms Sturgeon said: ldquoWersquoll see what the localsrsquo view is later on.Ms Fransen then butts in: ldquoThe locals what the ones you have flooded from other countries ldquoThe decent people of Scotland donrsquot want it flooded with immigrants.Ms Sturgeon tells her: ldquoYou are a fascist, you are a racist and the southside of Glasgow will reject you.Scotlandrsquos First Minister then walks away with party members as Ms Fransen pursues her, talking about ldquomass immigration and ldquoMarxism.Ms Fransen later tells an SNP supporter who asks her who she is: ldquoIrsquom not fascist, just a normal, decent unionist patriot.ldquoMy grandfather fought the Nazis.A scene from the confrontationIn a piece to camera uploaded by the British Freedom Party, she accuses Ms Sturgeon of ldquorunning away like a coward, adding: ldquoOf courseyou flood a constituency with foreigners and hardline republicans who absolutely hate Britain, hate the union, they are going to secure their votes.: Anas Sarwar mdash Voters in Glasgow will tell far-right candidate where to goldquoThe unionist community are no longer unrepresented and we are coming for you.Ms Fransen has previously been pictured outside the constituency office of Justice Secretary Humza Yousaf holding a sign saying ldquoitrsquos okay to be white and has said she is running against the ldquoSNP commie, Marxists, naughty people.The First Minister drew plaudits on social media for her reponse the right-wing activist- with one Twitter user saying "this is how a leader behaves".Another added: "This is great, Nicola. Good for you."Ms Sturgeon later Tweeted: "Glasgow Southside is the most erse and multi-cultural constituency in Scotland - one of the many things that makes it so brilliant. I am confident it will unite today to utterly reject these fascists."Glasgow Southside is the most erse and multi-cultural constituency in Scotland - one of the many things that makes it so brilliant. I am confident it will unite today to utterly reject these fascists. https:t.co ygPJRksOd

title: scottish-election-declaration-times-results---what-expect-today
story: Votes in some  of the  constituency seats will be counted from about am on Friday, with the first results expected from noon.It is anticipated all  should be declared by Friday evening.Then, from about am on Saturday, the remaining  constituency seats will be counted, after which the regional seats will be allocated.Due to the Covid- pandemic, there is a staggered tallying up of ballots for the  Holyrood election, with all results expected to be declared by Saturday evening.Normally, counting begins immediately after the polls close at pm and continues overnight, with results confirmed in the early hours.But the need for social distancing among count staff has meant votes will be tallied from Friday.This yearrsquos election, while conducted under the constraints of coronavirus rules, is also considered to be one of the most important since the Scottish Parliament opened in .With the SNP set for another five years in government, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon will no doubt ramp up the pressure on Westminster to grant the powers for another vote on Scottish independence.Her opponents in the Tory, Labour and Liberal Democrat parties have stressed the importance of focusing on Scotlandrsquos recovery from coronavirus insteadBut the SNP leader and her party have said no referendum will be held until after the immediate health crisis is over, and they insist powers gained through independence would actually improve the recovery in Scotland.Ms Sturgeon has said another pro-independence majority in the Scottish Parliament, including the Greens and Alba Party seats, should be enough to let Scots vote again on whether they want to leave the UK.Take a look at the potential declaration times here:

title: scottish-labour-confident-hartlepool-result-not-sign-things-come
story: Speaking to The Herald, several senior Labour party sources said the campaign in the English constituency had "everything" wrong with it, and could not be compared to their election campaign in Scotland.Hartlepool has just elected its first ever Conservative MP in Jill Mortimer, with Labours Dr Paul Williams losing out by a signicant amount.Ms Mortimer claimed victory in the by-election with , votes to Labours ,.One UK Labour source told the Herald: "This needs to be a wake-up call for us, but it is unlikely to be a similar picture in Scotland."Anas [Sarwar] has run a highly successful, energetic campaign and we are confident he has done a good job in Scotland, as have all the candidates."A Scottish Labour figure said the Hartlepool result was "absolutely not" a reflection of how the vote could go in Scotland, adding: "Anas has been received positively on every doorstep, and I hope that will show in the results."Im quietly confident."When asked whether the Hartlepool result was down to the party choosing the wrong candidate, orit was part of a wider sht, they said it was about "wrong everything" and added it was "absolutely not" an indication of how things could play out in Scotland.Another Scottish Labour source said: "Its devastating, but we have to keep positive. I dont think the issues are the same in Scotland as in Hartlepool and I dont think its a reflection of how we will do."They joked: "Mind you, that could be famous last words."Scottish Labour has been fighting it out with the Tories for second place in the Holyrood vote, with Anas Sarwar choosing to emphasise the need for recovery from the pandemic, and collaboration, rather than rows about the constitution.On the eve of poll, Nicola Sturgeon said she would work with the Scottish Labour party on policy issues, and said the party had some "good ideas".

title: scottish-election-poll-shows-independence-low-priority-list-snp-widespread-trust-voters
story: A YouGov survey for The Times indicates voters are more concerned with health, economic recovery and improving education over the next five years, instead of Scottish independence.When asked to list their top priorities for the new Scottish government, health and the economy came joint top, with each marked as a priority by  per cent of those surveyed.:Deep confusion over SNPs independence plans and misunderstanding of economic facts, think tank saysThe survey, which asked , people aged  or older between May  and May , also found education was third at  per cent, while climate change and the environment came fourth with  per cent of people listing it as a priority.Meanwhile, independence only came fth, after being listed as a priority by  per cent of people.Social care came sixth, at three points behind.According to the survey, less than halfof people who planned to vote SNP in their constituencies put independence in their top three priorities.In addition, it was only listed by  per cent of ldquoyes supporters.Ms Sturgeonrsquos opponents have attacked her plans to hold another vote on Scottish independence during the next Holyrood term, warning this will hinder the countryrsquos recovery ndash though she has insisted such a referendum will not take place until the immediate health crisis has passed.However, trust in the SNP proved to be high, with more than half of those surveyed for The Times YouGov surveysaying they had either a lot or a fair amount of confidence in the party to make the right decisions on the health service.Both health and the economy appear to be top of votersrsquo priorities for the next five years, judging by the poll.A total of  per cent of those surveyed said they would be confident in the decisions that will be made by finance secretary Kate Forbes and economy secretary Fiona Hyslop, presuming they both remain in those roles.Finance Secretary Kate Forbes and Economy Secretary Fiona Hyslop, However, forty-one per cent said they were not confident in the Scottish governmentrsquos abilities, leaving it with an overall score of plus .The SNP is certain to emerge again as the largest party in the Scottish Parliament after the election, but it wants to win an overall majority of MSPs as it pushes for a second independence referendum.It comes after research by the University of Bristol and Kingrsquos College London found that Scottish people are most likely to think the coronavirus pandemic has been dealt with badly and find Prime Minister Boris Johnson untrustworthy on Covid- issues.A majority of Scotsbelieve the pandemic has been mishandled by the UK Government.Dr Siobhan McAndrew, senior lecturer in quantitative social science at the University of Bristol, said: ldquoThe Scottish public are most likely to trust their own Government a great deal, as well as having the highest proportion saying their trust in the UK Government has fallen because of the pandemic.ldquoPerceptions of performance in relation to the pandemic appear to relate to political identication and trust as much as to appraisal of specic successes and failures.

title: coronavirus-under-40s-offered-alternative-astrazeneca-vaccine
story: The Joint Committee for Vaccination and Immunisation is not banning the use of the vaccine in this age group, but said where the Pfizer or Moderna vaccines were available theyshould be used preferentially as long as this does not cause any substantial delays to the vaccination programme.The JCVI also said that current modelling indicates that a possible third wave of the virus is likely to be smaller than previously expected.However, they stressed that this could changethere were a slowdown in the rate of the vaccine rollout or a dip in uptake, and urged young people to get vaccinated.: Healthy under-s in Glasgow area given AstraZeneca vaccine after guidance change told they had no alternativeThe UK still remains on track to give all adults a first vaccine dose by the end of July, according to Englands deputy chief medical officer Professor Jonathan Van Tam.The change follows a previous change in guidance which said that people under- should be offered an alternative to the Oxford-AstraZeneca vaccine.The change partly reflects the continued decline in rates of coronavirus in the community, which means the risk of being exposed to the virus is now much less than at earlier phases of the immunisation rollout.As a result, for younger people with no underlying health conditions - whose risk from Covid is very small - the benefit of vaccination in terms of preventing severe illness begins to be outweighed by the possibilityof developing a blood clot, even though the risk of that is also very slight.This is not the case for older age groups whose risk of serious disease from Covid is statistically higher.Where there is no alternative, under-s should still be offered the AstraZeneca vaccine as this was preferable in public health terms to any slowdown in vaccination - particularly amid growing evidence that the vaccines reduce transmission, and the risk of unvaccinated young people being able to spread the virus as the economy reopens.: Apology after small number of people in Edinburgh given double vaccine dose by mistakeHowever, there are thought to be no supply issues with offering the vast majority of younger people alternatives to AstraZeneca.Professor Wei Shen Lim, Covid- chairman for JCVI, said: "Safety remains our number one priority."We have continued to assess the benefit risk balance of Covid- vaccines in light of UK infection rates and the latest information from the MHRA on the extremely rare event of blood clots and low platelet counts following vaccination."As Covid- rates continue to come under control, we are advising that adults aged  to  years with no underlying health conditions are offered an alternative to the Oxford AstraZeneca vaccine,available andit does not cause delays in having the vaccine."The advice is specic to circumstances in the UK at this time and maximises use of the wide portfolio of vaccines available."The Covid- vaccines have already saved thousands of lives and the benefit for the majority of the population is clear -you are offered the vaccine, you should take it."Up to April , the Medicines and Healthcare Regulatory Agencysaid ithad received  reports of blood clots accompanied by low blood platelet count in the UK, all in people who had the AstraZeneca vaccine, out of around . million doses given.These clots occurred in  women and  men aged from  to , with  deaths.Six cases have been reported after a second dose.: Moray Covid surge linked to people not self-isolatingA particular type of brain blood clot - cerebral venous sinus thrombosis- was reported in  cases , and  had other major thromboembolic eventsaccompanied by low blood platelet count.The overall incidence of blood clots with low platelets after a first dose is put at . per million doses, and about one in a million for a second dose.For those aged  to  the incidence is . per million doses, and . per million for those aged  to .Overall, the death rate per million doses is ., but is . for those aged  to .MHRA chief executive Dr June Raine said: "Public safety is always at the forefront of our minds and we take every report seriously."Our position remains that the benefits of the Covid- vaccine AstraZeneca against Covid-, with its associated risk of hospitalisation and death, continues to outweigh the risks for the vast majority of people."The balance of benefits and risks is very favourable for older people but is more finely balanced for younger people and we advise that this evolving evidence should be taken into account when considering the use of the vaccine, as JVCI has done."Anyone who had a first dose of AstraZeneca without developing a blood clot, regardless of age, is urged to take up their second dose as planned.The regulator said people should seek medical attentionthey experience any of the following symptoms four days to four weeks after vaccination: asevere headache which is not relieved with painkillers or is getting worsea headache that feels worse when a person lies down or bends overa headache that is unusual and occurs with blurred vision, feeling or being sick, problems speaking, weakness, drowsiness or seizuresa rash that looks like small bruises or bleeding under the skin orshortness of breath, chest pain, leg swelling or persistent abdominal pain.

title: scottish-election-reports-record-voter-turnout-counting-way
story: Results are due to come in over two days as coronavirus safety measures ruled out the traditional overnight count.Votes in  of the  constituency seats began being counted at about am, with the first results expected in the afternoon.More than half of the countryrsquos constituencies expected to declare on Friday.And it appears Scots were not deterred by Thursdays challenging weather, after parts of the country saw snowfall, with reports of long lines and ballot boxes that were "too full".Nadeem Basharat, , said he and his partner Joanne Basharat, , went to Jordanhill Parish Church polling station at around .pm and were told they could not cast their vote at the time.He said he was told ballot box  was too full and he was told to ldquocome back by pm, by a steward who was ldquoquite vague.He said: ldquoWe went home and waited and got there for about .pm and managed to get in, ballot box  was still pretty full, like it had just been pushed down and not a new box.ldquoIt looked like there were people there who didnrsquot manage to vote first time around.But aspokesman for Glasgowrsquos ing officer said it was down to the "sheer size" of the regional paper, meaning some ballot boxes became full.Votes are poured out of a ballot box at the Emirates Arena in Glasgow ready for countingThey said: "We were able to deliver replacement boxes, but in this case some voters were asked to wait outside before voting.ldquoThe presiding officer is confident that all voters who were asked to wait were ultimately able to vote.Humza Yousaf, Scotlandrsquos Justice Secretary and a candidate for the Glasgow Pollok constituency, today arrived at the election count in the cityrsquos Emirates Arena, and saidthere had been high turnout at many polling stations in his constituency and around the country.Speaking to reporters, the SNP candidate said the last six weeks had been a campaign ldquolike no other.He said: ldquoWersquove only been able to knock doors for the last three weeks, normally we would have done months and months of canvassing.ldquoSo really strange in that respect, dficult to get a feel on the doors because of that lack of data coming back.Saying the SNP were feeling buoyant, Mr Yousaf said: ldquoThere is people who will take a high turnout as a positive sign for them, but I suspect every party will say that.:Poll shows independence low on priority list but SNP has widespread trust of votersHe added: ldquoI think the SNPrsquos going to have a good night, but I think other parties also I can see therersquos an uptick in their vote too.ldquoSo really itrsquos going to come down to the wire in some seats I suspect.The Glasgow Pollok constituency is expected to declare later on Friday.Meanwhile,Jason Allardyce, editor of the Sunday Times Scotland, wrote on Twitter today: "Turnout for #Holyrood seems to be up - possibly even reaching a record level."The final total of voters registered for the Scottish Parliament election has been confirmed at ,, ndash the highest electorate ever for a Scottish Parliament election.Candidates in the closely-contested Holyrood seat of Edinburgh Southern have welcomed the high turnout of postal votes as counting continues.The seat was won by Scottish Labourrsquos Daniel Johnson at the  election, defeating then SNP incumbent Jim Eadie by a majority of , votes.Edinburgh Southern was also the only constituency in Scotland to elect a Labour MP, Ian Murray, to Westminster at the  general election.The Holyrood seat is a key target for the SNP as it aims for an overall majority.Across the six Edinburgh constituencies, the postal vote turnout was .%, with a record , ballots ed, according to the council.Mr Johnson said he is ldquofeeling positive as the initial postal votes started to be counted, while SNP challenger Catriona MacDonald said she feels ldquoquite hopeful given the turnout of her partyrsquos supporters on Thursday.She told the PA news agency: ldquoIn our strongest areas, people were really, really engaged and really keen to go out and vote, even despite the weather.ldquoWe had people queuing outside the polling place in hail and rain, but I went round to pretty much every polling place and it was really positive. Catriona MacDonald , Miles Briggsand Daniel Johnson , watch as votes are counted for the Scottish Parliamentary Elections at the Highland Hall in Ingleston, Edinburgh." alt"HeraldScotland: Three candidates for the Edinburgh Southern constituencyCatriona MacDonald , Miles Briggsand Daniel Johnson , watch as votes are counted for the Scottish Parliamentary Elections at the Highland Hall in Ingleston, Edinburgh." class"editor-image"Three candidates for the Edinburgh Southern constituencyCatriona MacDonald , Miles Briggsand Daniel Johnson , watch as votes are counted for the Scottish Parliamentary Elections at the Highland Hall in Ingleston, Edinburgh.ldquoThere have been a lot more postal votes than usual ndash itrsquos about , postal votes in our constituency.ldquoGiven the very unusual circumstances of the election itrsquos probably not surprising, but itrsquos a really positive thing so no-one misses out.Speaking shortly before midday, Mr Johnson said: ldquoThe turnout looks like itrsquos been very strong, there was queuing at the polls and most importantly we were getting a very positive reaction on the doors ndash we werenrsquot necessarily sure that that would be the case.ldquoSo wersquoll have to see what the count brings us, but Irsquom feeling good about the campaign wersquove run and wersquoll see what final tallies are.Scottish Conservative Miles Briggs is also contesting the constituency and ndash as with Mr Johnson ndash is also top of his partyrsquos regional list ballot.He told PA: ldquoSpeaking to Conservative activists, we were happy that we turned out our voters and our supporters, and we were getting great feedback yesterday.ldquoThe campaignrsquos been very dferent, wersquove tried to get people to register for postal votes, that seems to be successful.ldquoWe have obviously seen a huge increase in the turnout as well so wersquoll need to wait and see what sort of impact that has.ldquoWersquove run a positive campaign and wersquove tried to focus people on lending us their regional list vote, and from the early indications wersquove seen already from postal votes, we seem to be winning these across the three seats which are being counted today.ldquoSo Irsquom really optimistic about what that presents for the final result here in Lothian.

title: scottish-election-2021-majority-tracker
story: As results come in, were adding up the party totals and telling you exactly how far each party is from that crucial  - the amount needed to get a majority in parliament.View the latest results in full with our election tracker, and keep up to date with our live blog for all the latest updates and commentary.The below chart simply shows the total number of seats each party has obtained so far, with a line positioned at . As the next few days progress, we should see these totals creeping closer to that line.And this one is perhaps a bit more fun - or at least it will be when we have more results.This moving graph shows how the votes have changed over time. Were updating this every minute the results are announced, to give us a clear view at the end of the next few days of how the results transpired.

title: neil-mackay-snp-must-tell-scotland-independence-means
story: Either the SNP will gain an outright majority, or lose out by a slim margin but with Greens added in Yes parties will have a clear mandate from the Scottish people to begin negotiations with the UK government for a second referendum.Unseemly though it may be amid pandemic, the electoral mathematics demand the SNP now comes up with a new prospectus for independence which can be presented to the Scottish people.Although most Yes supporters donrsquot want another referendum until Covid is beaten, Scotland cannot be left in the dark any longer about the fine detail of our constitutional future - especiallya standoff will inevitably take place with Boris Johnson over a second referendum.If wersquore going into a constitutional crisis we cannot be passive observers. Now the voting is over, we need to know what independence really means.To read the rest of this analysis, sign up to The Heralds new political newsletter, Unspun, and get unrivalled political analysisevery day at pm. here.

title: snp-secures-first-gain-holyrood-election-winning-east-lothian
story: The party took the seat with a majority of , over Labour, which has held the constituencysince the start of devolution.:Scottish election LIVE as results arrive from across the countryIt is the first of the key marginals to be declared in the Scottish Parliament election, and the first opposition-held seat the SNP has taken.The SNP secured , votes to Labours ,.Labour sources had declared the constituency battle "close" ahead of the declaration.

title: keir-starmer-labour-lost-trust-working-people
story: Speaking this afternoon Mr Starmer vowed to do "whatever is necessary to fix" the failure among working class people he claims is to blame for the Conservatives taking the constituency for the first time in its history.He said he was "bitterly disappointed" and said: "I take full responsibility for the results ndash and I will take full responsibility for fixing this.ldquoWe have changed as a party but we havenrsquot set out a strong enough case to the country.ldquoVery often we have been talking to ourselves instead of to the country and we have lost the trust of working people, particularly in places like Hartlepool.ldquoI intend to do whatever is necessary to fix that."The leader has come under fire from all sides since the result was declared overnight, with several high profile figures including Lord Adonis calling for him to step down.However Mr Starmer said he was the right person to lead Labour, and will make a plan to "reconnect" with voters.He said: "I will set out what change is needed over the next few days, but Irsquom absolutely clear in my mind and absolutely determined to do whatever is necessary to fix things and to make sure we can make that case to the country in a compelling way.He went on: ldquoI will set out what we need to do to reconnect the Labour Party to the voters that have cast their verdict on us last night, particularly in places like Hartlepool.Several Labour grandees this morning sought to blame Jeremy Corbyn for the poor result, with Peter Mandelson, the former MP for the area, saying he was still casting a "dark cloud" over the party.However MPsJohn McDonnell and Diane Abbott, allies of Mr Corbyn, denied it was related to the former leader and urged Keir Starmer to change tack.Ms Abbott said on social media it was "not possible to blame Jeremy Corbyn for this result".She added: "Labour won the seat twice under his leadership. Keir Starmer must think again about his strategy."

title: moray-public-reassured-claims-covid-tests-can-fooled-tomato-ketchup
story: NHSGrampian issued advice reassuring the public as they deal with an outbreak of the virus.The latest statistics show Morayhas . cases per , area,signicantly higher than the rate in the rest of the country.Thehealthboard has launched an incident management teamto try to bring the virus back under control, and is urging people to get tested eventhey do not have symptoms.Door-to-door testing is being ldquoheavily considered for Elgin, the epicentre of the outbreak.:Coronavirus in Moray: Under s offered Covid- jab to control outbreakNHS Grampian took to social media this afternoon to correct re rumoursthat rising case numbers were due to people fooling tests.They said in a tweet: "We cant quite believe we have to say this, but here goes: rising case numbers in Moray are not the result of people fooling Lateral Flow Devices with tomato ketchup ."A positive Lateral Flow Device test is always followed up with a PCR test to confirm the result."This is the gold standard of testing. % of the positive LFD tests in Moray have been confirmed as positive by PCR testing."Please set aside the rumours and hearsay. The situation in Moray is real and it is serious."We are seeing people requiring hospital treatment as a result of COVID- infection."We need people to #ProtectMoray, stick to the guidelines, and take up the expanded testing offer."We cant quite believe we have to say this, but here goes: rising case numbers in Moray are not the result of people fooling Lateral Flow Devices with tomato ketchup .Today, a mobile testing unit has arrived in Elgin as part of an effort to tackle escalating Covid- levels in the Moray region.The unit is initially targeting pupils and teachers at Elgin Academy during school hours and will be used for members of the wider public during the weekend.NHs Grampian added: "To everyone in Aberdeenshire and Aberdeen City, remember this virus can go wherever it wants and certainly doesnt respect local authority boundaries."Take care of yourselves, take care of your community, and lets keep going."

title: snp-take-ayr-conservatives-second-gain

title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: covid 19 vaccinations open for 18 to 29 year olds
story: coronavirusCOVID- vaccinations to open for  to -year-oldsMay ,  at : pmNHS Orkney has today confirmed that those aged  to  will be offered their first COVID- vaccination appointments at The Balfour, starting this month.The dates for these will be Saturday, May  Sunday, May  and Saturday, June . Letters will be sent out to these patients in the week commencing Monday, May  detailing when to attend for their vaccine.Letters are also being sent out this week to all patients aged  to  who have not yet had a first vaccine, inviting them to phone the vaccination centre to book in for this. The telephone number for the vaccination centre is   .Maureen Firth, NHS Orkney head of primacy care services, said: #We will be sending out further letters towards the end of next week to all patients who attended the Pickaquoy Centre for their first vaccine.#These letters will detail where patients should go to get their second vaccine. These vaccines will be given at the Balfour and the Kirkwall Vaccination Centre so, please read your letter carefully to know where to go.Ms Firth also revealed that: #we are due to vaccinate in the region of , patients during May. #We would therefore please ask that you attend at the time you are given unless you have an urgent reason to ask for this to be rescheduled. This will make our logistics and planning so much easier.#Thank you so much for your support during this vaccination programme, it has been much appreciated.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: driving tests finally given the green light
story: Delighted learner drivers in Orkney are among the first in Scotland to be able to sit a driving test once more, but some are concerned over a #random# allocation of tests.Driving tests on the Scottish mainland will not resume until May , but in Orkney, they restarted on Monday, April .Instructors and learners expressed relief, but Orkney’s MP has slammed the Driver and Vehicle Standards Agencyfor a lack of “creative thinking,” as close to  Orkney learners found themselves in a growing backlog in recent months.Alix Fletcher, , from Burray was the first learner back at the test centre in Kirkwall since December, and passed on Monday morning.Although she was thrilled to have passed her test, she says it’s a little odd that she was the first to be offered one, as she only joined the waiting list in March this year.Alix said: “It just seems like the system is picking everybody up randomly. There must be loads of people on the waiting list in Orkney before I’ve been put in.”Driving instructor Robin Nicolson was delighted to be getting back under way. “It’s a big relief to us and it’s big relief I’m sure to the pupils that they can start getting a test.#Full story available in this week#s edition of The Orcadian, available now.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: feline finds fame after election count invasion
story: The owner of a cat who had to be ejected from the Orkney election count has shared her surprise after her favourite found national fame.Hannah Ker from Kirkwall was in stitches after spotting footage of her tortoiseshell Lola on both local and national news.The moggy made a surprise entrance at the Pickaquoy Centre arena, this morning, much to the amusement of count staff.After a quick wander to check that counting procedures were up to scratch, Lola was soon escorted from the premises.It wasn’t long before footage of the cat’s unexpected visit appeared on the national news, amid more standard coverage of the elections. Other news outlets soon picked up the story, while local commentators suggested that the cat might make a “purrrfect” late entry candidate.“We often wonder what Lola gets up to when we are working so we couldn’t believe our surprise when we seen her on the national news,” Miss Ker told The Orcadian.”She has always been such a friendly cat so it was no surprise she was away making new friends.“We always knew our little Lola would be destined for big things.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: navy divers to receive freedom of orkney honour
story: newsNavy ers to receive Freedom of Orkney honourMay ,  at : pm vw, px"  The Royal Navy Northern Diving Group will have the Freedom of Orkney bestowed upon them in recognition of the group#s historic connection in commemorating those lost in the sinking of the HMS Royal Oak.Every year, the ers change the White Ensign on the wreck of the Royal Oak which was torpedoed while at anchor in Scapa Flow on October , , with the loss of  lives.Due to COVID restrictions,  was the first year since the recovery of the ship#s bell in  that the northern ing group was not able to change the White Ensign and pay tribute to those who lost their lives.The group and its predecessors have also assisted in disposing of historic ordinances such as mines, torpedoes and grenades on  occasions, and have assisted authorities in a wide range of commemorations and events over the years.Those who have also received the Freedom of Orkney include artist Stanley Cursiter, writer Ernest Marwick, navy ship HMS Orkney, the Queen#s Own Highlanders, and most recently Dr John Rae.At a meeting of the full council today , Orkney Islands Council councillors approved to confer the honour upon the ing group.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: positivity in the air as new lambs appear
story: Lambing season is in full swing, as new born lambs have sprung up in fields across the county.Grahame Hourie, of Heathfield Farm in St Ola, has seen an average of  to  lambs born every day of the season so far, but that number is starting to slow down.Predominantly Texel and Cheviot crosses, Grahame says they’ve now overseen about , to , new lambs at the farm.According to Grahame, the season up to now has been fortunate in more ways than one.“Weather-wise has been very good. The winter that we had before — with the really cold snow — has kept the sheep in good condition, because they stayed around the feeders, they didn’t have to wander far and look for anything.#They’re in good condition this year, they’re looking well, so it’s been good all-round the weather.”Also, previous years have seen serious problems caused by ravens attacking and killing newborn lambs.“We had a massive problem last year with ravens,” Grahame said, “but for some reason — I don’t know what’s happened —we’ve seen next-to-no ravens this year. I’ve only seen maybe four at the very most in the fields.Meanwhile, prices of cattle and sheep have been very good, despite of the dficult operating conditions brought by COVID restrictions.“They’re sky-high,” said Grahame, “we’re just hoping they stay there!”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: recovery is the number one priority for re elected orkney msp
story: Liam McArthur has said that Orkney#s recovery from the fallout of the COVID- pandemic will be his number one priority as he enters a new Scottish Parliamentary term.Mr McArthur told The Orcadian that he was delighted to retained his seat in Orkney, which he has served for the past  years.Asked about his key hopes for the next five years, the Scottish Liberal Democrat MSP said: #I think the unying thing I would like to see for Orkney, the Highlands and Islands and Scotland is a focus on recovery. That recovery will be dferent in dferent parts of the country.#I#ve said consistently throughout this campaign — and what Willie Rennie has been saying nationally — is that that focus on recovery has to be the number one priority.#Mr McArthur was ed to his seat with , of , votes.SNP candidate Robert Leslie came second in the race with a total of , votes.Sam Bown, of the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party received  votes.Scottish Labour candidate, Coilla Drake, gained  votes.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: labour-hold-ground-north-wales-election-counting-continues
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Senedd electionWelsh Labour appears to have exceeded expectations as counting for the Welsh Parliament election continues.Only one of Walesrsquo so-called red wall seats, the Vale of Clwyd, fell to the Welsh Conservatives, while Labour sources are also confident of unseating the former Plaid Cymru leader Leanne Wood in Rhondda.Changes to ensure social distancing at venues means counting for all constituencies may not finish on Friday, which would see the process being adjourned until Saturday morning.Some regional counts also look set to be pushed back to Saturday.Thank you to all of the brilliant Welsh Labour activists who have worked tirelessly over the last weeks and months. While we now wait for the results, you can be proud of everything wersquove achieved together.mdash Welsh LabourMay , At the start of the election campaign, polling suggested Labour was facing its worst ever result and was at risk of winning as few as  of the Seneddrsquos  seats, a loss of seven from .After voting polls closed at pm on Thursday, party sources said retaining all of its seats in the Senedd remained ldquoa massive challenge.But on Friday evening, confirmed results as well as indications from parties contesting seats across the country means Mark Drakefordrsquos party is confident of ending up just short of an outright majority once again.The First Minister said Labourrsquos performance reflected the ldquoreal enthusiasm he had encountered on doorsteps.ldquoI started this campaign answering questions as to why this was going to be Labourrsquos worst-ever result, a poll prediction of  seats, he said.ldquoThe campaign never felt like that to me. Wersquove had a fantastic and energetic campaign with hundreds of people involved and real enthusiasm on the doorstep, so that never seemed to me to genuinely reflect the mood here in Wales.Mr Drakeford said it was ldquotoo early to say whether results meant Labour could win an outright majority.Walesrsquo health minister Vaughan Gething said Labour had fought hard to win back the trust of voters in North Wales.Wrexham, Clwyd South and Delyn, were all held despite being targeted by the Tories after they flipped them from Labour in the  general election." data-title"POLITICS Elections" data--holder"PA Graphics" data--notice"PA Graphics Press Association Images" data-credit"PA Graphics" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eedadfbddcYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjIwNTAMjQw ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eedadfbddcYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjIwNTAMjQw ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eedadfbddcYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjIwNTAMjQw ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"ldquoWersquove absolutely had to re-earn the trust of the people of Wales in every part of Wales. Wersquove taken nothing for granted, wersquove absolutely not been complacent, Mr Gething said.ldquoThe Tories put a lot of heavy artillery into North Wales. The Prime Minister visited several times, the Chancellor was there, Andrew RT Davies was there on regular occasions, and they launched their manesto in Wrexham.Mr Gething said indications of a stronger Labour result than was predicted could help the UK party following its Westminster by-election defeat in Hartlepool.Askedhe had a message for Sir Keir Starmer about the direction of the Labour Party should go in, Mr Gething said: ldquoThe message for all of us is keep on listening to what the public are saying.ldquoDonrsquot tell the public theyrsquore wrong when they vote, try to understand why theyrsquove chosen to vote in a dferent way. Listen and do the right things that are consistent with our values.ldquoYou canrsquot simply assume that people will continue to vote for you as a result of old tribal loyalty.Welsh Tory leader in the Senedd Andrew RT Davies said his partyrsquos taking of Vale of Clwyd from Labour was a ldquobrilliant result, but suggested traditional Labour voters who voted Tory in the  general election had now ldquocome home.Mr Davies told the PA news agency: ldquoIt does seem from other seats that have been declared in other parts of Wales that the Labour voters have come home to it after the, shall we say, Brexit election of .Labour may also find comfort that the Vale of Clwyd loss was only by a small margin, with Tory Gareth Davies receiving , votescompared to Labour Jason McLellanrsquos , .Labour sources also say they are confident of taking Rhondda from Plaid Cymru, which they lost to incumbent Leanne Wood at the  election.The final make-up of the next Senedd may not be confirmed until the weekendresults in some constituencies are close and recounts are called.No party has ever won an outright majority in Wales, meaning the party which has won the most seats will be expected to enter into talks with other parties or independent members in order to form the next Welsh Government.copy -. title: can-go-holiday
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.A woman wearing flip flops on a beachThe Government has announced the green, amber and red lists for international travel.Here the PA news agency answers  key questions on what this means for holidaymakers:# INTERNATIONAL TRAVEL UPDATE #The ban on non-essential international travel will be removed on the th May and replaced with a traffic light system #This means it will no longer be illegal to travel abroad without a permitted reason pic bOIaJKcimdash Rt Hon Grant Shapps MPMay , ndash Why are the lists important They determine the quarantine and coronavirus testing requirements people will face when ing to England once the ban on overseas leisure travel is lted on May .ndash Why is everyone talking about the green list Travellers ing from a country on that list will not be need to quarantine, and will only be required to take one post-arrival test.ndash Sounds good. Whatrsquos on it It consists of Portugal, Gibraltar, Israel, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Brunei, Iceland and the Faroe Islands, plus several small remote islands which are British Overseas Territories." data-title"Israel" data--holder"PA Archive" data--notice"PA Archive PA Images" data-credit"Adam Davy" data-usage-terms"" srcset"https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eefdebcfdebfbcYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjENjkODIy ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eefdebcfdebfbcYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjENjkODIy ..jpg w w, https:image.assets.pressassociation.io v image production eefdebcfdebfbcYudGVudHNlYXJjaGFwaSwxNjENjkODIy ..jpg w w" sizes" vw,vw,px, px"Beach volleyball on one of Tel Avivrsquos beaches ndash So I can go on holiday to anywhere on that list Not quite. Entry to Australia, New Zealand, Singapore, Brunei and the Faroe Islands is severely restricted.ndash Where can I go Portugal plans to welcome UK tourists who have had a recent negative test, have recovered from the virus and therefore have antibodies, or had both doses of a vaccine.Gibraltar will not require UK visitors to be tested or vaccinated, whereas Israel will initially reopen its border on May  only to groups of foreign tourists who have had both jabs.None of these destinations will require arrivals to quarantine.##Portugal including the Azores and Madeira##Israel##Australia##New Zealand##Singapore##Iceland##Brunei##Faroe Islands##Gibraltar##Falkland Islandsmdash Rt Hon Grant Shapps MPMay , ndash What about the amber list That covers the most popular holiday destinations such as Spain, France, Italy and Greece.Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said ldquoyou should not be travelling to these places right nowndash WhatI go against that guidance People ing from amber countries must take two post-arrival tests.They are also required to self-isolate at home for  days, although they can reduce that timethey take an additional negative test on day-five.In addition to the above, the MALDIVES, NEPAL and TURKEY will be added to the Red List. Passengers arriving into England after am on th May MUST undertake a ten day stay in a managed quarantine hotel.More information below #https:t.co vhwHMEuvmdash Rt Hon Grant Shapps MPMay , ndash How about the red list Those ing from a red list country must stay in a quarantine hotel for  nights at a cost of pound,.ndash Will the lists change The lists can be amended at any time, but wholesale changes are not expected to occur until the situation is reviewed at a ldquocheckpoint on June .ndash How does the Government decide which countries are on each list There are four key tests that the Government will take into account when deciding how to categorise a country within the traffic light system.These include the percentage of the countryrsquos population to have been vaccinated, the rate of infection, the prevalence of iants of concern and the countryrsquos access to reliable scientic data and genomic sequencing.ndash What about vaccine passports Grant Shapps confirmed that people in England will be able to demonstrate they have had both doses of a vaccine through the NHS app.ndash Can people living in Scotland, Wales or Northern Ireland go on a foreign holiday The devolved administrations have not set dates for the restart of overseas leisure travel, although announcements are expected in the coming days.Grant Shapps there was ldquoa large degree of agreement and cooperation in developing the system.copy -. support as possible during these challenging times.Anas SarwarScottish Labour have lost one of their three Scottish Parliament seats but deputy leader Jackie Baillie has retained Dumbarton with an increased majority.Ms Baillie won , votes, compared to , for the SNPrsquos Tony Giugliano.In , the Dumbarton seat went to Ms Baillie by just  votes, but on Friday she increased her majority to ,.Scottish Labour leader Anas Sarwar lost out to Nicola Sturgeon in Glasgow Southside but said he was pleased to increase his partyrsquos share of the vote in the constituency.Daniel Johnson held Edinburgh Southern on , votes to SNP candidate Catriona MacDonaldrsquos ,.But Martin Whitfield lost East Lothian ndash which had been won in  by the retiring MSP Iain Gray ndash to the SNPrsquos Paul McLennan.Mr Sarwar lost to the First Minister in his home constituency but is also a candidate on the regional list, which will be declared on Saturday.As results were announced at the Emirates Arena on Friday, Mr Sarwar won , votes to Ms Sturgeonrsquos ,.In , the First Minister won a total of , votes ndash with the Labour candidate winning , votes.Speaking to the PA news agency after the result, he said: ldquoIrsquom pleased that we doubled the actual number of votes that we got and we increased the share of our vote by %.ldquoI think you can see the immense progress we have made in the last  weeks.He said Labour was still on a journey to build a ldquocredible alternative to the SNP.Saying he welcomed the increased turnout, he added: ldquoIrsquom not one of those politicians who likes to calculate whether a higher turnout or a lower turnout is good or bad for their inidual political party.ldquoI think itrsquos good for democracy that as many people participate as possible.Discussing East Lothian, he said: ldquoItrsquos disappointing, therersquos no point in denying it.ldquoOf course Irsquom particularly disappointed for our amazing candidate Martin Whitfield.Polls are now closed. I want to say thank you to my campaign team, our incredible candidates, activists, supporters and all across Scotland who took part in the democratic process.I am so proud of the positive and forward looking campaign we have ran, together. pic zYNcsELmdash Anas SarwarMay , ldquoBut again, look at where we were  weeks ago ndash we were at % in the opinion polls and coming fourth.ldquoEven my biggest critics can see that over the course of the last  weeks wersquove got the Labour Party back on the pitch.ldquoI think people can see that Irsquom a dferent kind of leader, trying to build a dferent kind of party, and together rebuild a dferent kind of country.copy -. title: labour-claims-extraordinary-results-welsh-parliament-election
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Coronavirus – Tue Mar , Mark Drakefordrsquos Welsh Labour has declared its strong Senedd election performance as ldquoan extraordinary set of results in extraordinary times as the party look favourite to retain control of the Welsh Government.The party has exceeded expectations as counting for the Welsh Parliament election continues, having so far lost just one of its seats and taking Rhondda from Plaid Cymrursquos former leader Leanne Wood.Polling at the start of the campaign suggested Labour was facing its worst ever result and was at risk of winning as few as  of the Seneddrsquos  seats, a loss of seven from , though later polls suggested a stronger showing. vw,vw,px, px"After voting closed at pm on Thursday, party sources said retaining all of its seats in the Senedd remained ldquoa massive challenge.Commenting on the ldquoremarkable turnaround on Friday evening, a Labour spokesperson said: ldquoIt is increasingly clear that people across Wales have put their faith in Welsh Labour and Mark Drakeford to lead the next Welsh Government and lead Wales out of the pandemic.Health minister Vaughan Gething held his Cardf South and Penarth seat with , votes , a increase of , votes from , and said Labour and Mr Drakefordrsquos handling of the coronavirus pandemic was a ldquomajor factor in the partyrsquos results.He told the PA news agency: ldquoWersquove had to make le-changing choices that affected every single family in the country.ldquoThe pandemic has thrust the First Minister in the spotlight, and most people like what theyrsquove seen in the way hersquos handled the pandemic.ldquoWhat we now need to do is understand what that means for the future government for Wales, how we handle this next phase finishing up the pandemic response, and then the dficult task of recovery ndash one that I think wersquore in the best possible place for.Mr Drakeford said earlier on Friday that signs of a strong Labour performance reflected the ldquoreal enthusiasm he had encountered on doorsteps.Labour are on  seats, the Tories on eight, and Plaid Cymru on five with two more constituency declarations to go, including Mr Drakefordrsquos Cardf West constituency.Labour said Plaid Cymru had ldquoimploded in losing its Rhondda seat to Labourrsquos Elizabeth Buffy Williams and failing to take target seats Llanelli and Aberconwy.Rhonddarsquos outgoing MS, Leanne Wood, told ITV Wales the result was ldquodisappointing, but said her party ran a ldquoclean and honest campaign.Labourrsquos strong results will minimise its reliance on other parties in order to form a government, with Plaid previously thought as the most likely to enter into a coalition with them were Labour some way short of a majority.Only one of Walesrsquo so-called red wall seats, the Vale of Clwyd, fell to the Welsh Conservatives.Wrexham, Clwyd South and Delyn, were all held despite being targeted by the Tories after they flipped them from Labour in the  general election.Welsh Tory leader in the Senedd Andrew RT Davies said his partyrsquos taking of Vale of Clwyd from Labour was a ldquobrilliant result, but suggested traditional Labour voters who voted Tory in the  general election had now ldquocome home.Mr Davies told the PA news agency: ldquoIt does seem from other seats that have been declared in other parts of Wales that the Labour voters have come home to it after the, shall we say, Brexit election of .The final make-up of the next Senedd will not be confirmed until the weekend with final regional results expected on Saturday.copy -. title: judges head north in bid to home in on winner
story: on BBC Scotland this Wednesday.Self-build Da Hen Run in Burra, owned by Wendy and Maurice Inkster, and Julie Talbot and Gary Mainland’s renovated croft house at Evrabister in Kergord will be showcased in the popular BBC series.Mrs Inkster, who created and runs Burra Bears from a workshop in her home, said she decided to apply for the programme in “a bit of a mad moment”.She said: “I watched the first series and part of the way through it I decided to apply. I never thought they would even get back to me.”Her application in  came too late for the second series of the programme but the producers promised to keep her in mind for any subsequent series.Mrs Inkster said she was “quite flattered” to be asked last yearDa Hen Run could feature, adding: “Loads of folk apply obviously, so I was a bit surprised.”The film crew arrived last September, under strict Covid guidance, and Mrs Inkster said she and her husband had to “disappear for a few hours” while the judges, interior designer Anna Campbell-Jones, architect Michael Angus and lestyle blogger Kate Spiers, rummaged around their house.“I didn’t mind them being there, but I was a bit worried about every bit of my house being on national TV,” she said.“I was a bit worried that we were going to leave something lying around.”She joked that the programme was a “great incentive” to get some early spring cleaning done.Askedshe had left any Burra Bears lying around the sitting-room for the judges to eye, she replied: “I don’t think I hid any in the actual living room, I thought they might think that was advertising.”She said she was not surethe judges had looked around the workshop that she uses to design and create the bears.Similarly, Ms Talbot said she had decided to apply “on a whim” after enjoying last year’s series of the show, which featured Iain and Suzanne Malcolmson’s home in South Nesting.She said: “I loved the peerie fisherman’s cottage in Orkney and thought, ‘why not enter my peerie house ’“Also, it prompted Gary to very kindly undertake some DIY to the cottage before filming commenced.”..Reporter since . title: new turbine blades make an arrival
story: Operator Shetland Aerogenerators Ltd says the arrival serves as a reminder of its ongoing investment in its site.Chief executive David Thomson said it came as part of a plan to keep Burradale operational #for a long time to come#.#These turbines went up over  years ago and we expect them to continue producing energy for many more years,# he said.#We frequently have to renew major components and this year we decided our blades are due some extra attention.#We did something similar  years ago and it’s the right time to look at them again.#He added the blades would be swapped with the old ones when a suitable weather window emerges.#The blades are a good example of how our business looks to reduce waste, reuse elements and recycle only as a last resort.#He said the new set of blades had been sourced from another site before being refurbished to give another  years of le.#Our removed blades will go to be similarly refurbished and, eventually, a set from Burradale can be used on someone ’s project.#This gives each blade several ‘lives’, which is the most environmentally friendly way to operate.#Mr Thomson said there had been some disruption following their arrival #because it is good practice to involve an escort for loads of this #.#We’re grateful to Police Scotland for helping us minimise the disturbance.#..Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. title: under 40s to be given pfizer vaccine following new advice
story: People in their thirties will receive the Pfizer vaccine for their first dose, following advice they should not be given AstraZeneca where possible.The new guidance has come from the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisation , which says that alternatives should be found for the under s.NHS Shetland has subsequently had a rethink how it will deliver vaccines to the younger age group.It says anyone in this group who has already received AstraZeneca will receive the same vaccine for their second dose.The JCVI advice changed after a review on extremely rare blood clot-related side effects.But NHS Shetland has stressed this does not mean AstraZeneca can not be used in this age group # only that an alternative is preferred.The JCVI had already changed the guidelines for the - age group.Interim director of public health Dr Susan Laidlaw said the risk of clotting complications in those under  who received AstraZeneca was very low.“The JCVI is clear that in the - group, any of the UK vaccines is better than no vaccine, unless there are specic medical contra-indications,# she said.#There may be some circumstances where NHS Shetland may still offer AstraZeneca because it is the only one that is practical under specic circumstances.”More than , first doses and , second doses have already been completed in Shetland with more than  people vaccinated at Gilbertson Park on Thursday...Ryan Taylor has worked as a reporter since , and has been at The Shetland Times since , covering a wide iety of news topics.Before then he reported for other newspapers in the Highlands, where he was raised, and in Fe, where he began his career with DC Thomson. He also has experience in broadcast journalism with Grampian Television. He has lived in Shetland since , where he harbours an unhealthy interest in old cars and motorbikes.The Mousa Broch should now be within easy reach of visitors, thanks to a decision to restart runs of the Mousa boat.
